Award.AwardTitle: EBP: The Digital NEST: Building Pathways to Computing Education and Careers for Latino/a Youth

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This work examines the extent to which community-based technology centers that incorporate open educational resources can provide the educational structure needed to motivate and prepare underserved high school students, particularly Latino/a students in rural communities, for careers in computer science (CS). Community centers are uniquely positioned to provide access to relevant technology and instruction, scaffolding for CS learning, and a network of support, but there is little research on how to optimize their impact for youth that are poorly served by their local school systems. This project will lead to a model for other community technology centers to build educational and career pathways by leveraging online resources, linking them to national CS standards as well as local industry needs and supporting that learning with effective mentorship. It will result in a set of recommended strategies that informal education centers can use to effectively deliver and complement formal school-based CS education.

This is a partnership between a research organization, ETR Associates and the Digital NEST, a community technology center that serves Latino/a high school students. The work examines the efficacy of a suite of educational techniques tailored specifically for CS education in informal settings. The pedagogical component focuses on the effective use of badges as motivational learning devices through the development of digital credentials. Students will engage in hybrid online CS courses aligned with CSTA K-12 CS standards. In the process, this work assesses the social and motivational factors that affect engagement and retention in CS education in community-based informal settings. Given that less than a quarter of all high schools in the United States offer formal computing education, this research is positioned to address the growing need for CS education in informal settings and particularly students in rural settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efforts to broaden participation in computing in K-12 focus primarily on schools; less is known about how to leverage out-of-school time. This study involved a research-practice partnership between two non-profit organizations. The following research questions were addressed:

  1. Does participation in informal educational opportunities at a community technology center promote high school students? skills, identity, and motivation to pursue and persist in computer science (CS)?
  2. How can digital badges play a role in CS learning?
  3. How and why do youth participate, and what role do relationships with peers and mentors play?

Data were collected from 114 youth over time using a combination of surveys and interviews, and from eight staff members through meeting notes and structured interviews.

Intellectual Merit

The study contributes to an understanding of the role of context in CS engagement and learning. Using an ecological approach, the results show how institutional and relational supports (e.g., mentors and staff) help students navigate the barriers to their educational and workforce goals without giving up their cultural values and their existing networks of support. The results provide a better understanding of the role that informal learning settings play in efforts to broad participation in computing. Students came primarily for access to technology, career development and support. The reasons youth participate change over time, and youth are motivated to become contributing members because of their connections to staff, a sense of belonging, and the recognition that they will learn skills and obtain knowledge that will give them a head start on their college and career pathways. While they spend their time learning technical skills, it was also important for them to have a place to hang out, do homework, and socialize with friends. The benefits include a sense of confidence as well as exposure to different technical industries and the development of workplace skills that range from more technical to the soft skills that are needed to succeed in today?s tech workforce. The findings also show the range of ways that staff serve as informal mentors that play a critical role in how the youth participate, and how they make decisions about and navigate their educational and career pathways.  There is a progression from building trust to teaching skills, but most of the natural mentoring is about guidance and support. The project also generated findings that can be used to guide the development of research-practice partnerships with community-based organizations. This includes the importance of having open conversations about the role of culture, power, and privilege before the research questions are finalized and any data are collected.  

 

Broader Impacts

The results of this study have implications for community technology centers and other informal and voluntary learning settings that aim to engage youth in computing education, particularly those in rural and low socioeconomic communities. The data provide insights into who comes to the center, why they come, and what strategies are effective for engaging Latinx youth in learning computing skills in informal settings. This project also produced insights on how to help CTCs employ data-driven decision-making and can inform other CTCs on how to develop assessment systems like digital badges, and the most effective strategies for engaging and supporting a range of youth in tech learning and activities that build a career and education pathway. The project produced a list of eight tips to help programs develop and sustain effective digital badging systems. 

 


Last Modified: 05/15/2019
Modified by: Jill Denner
